sp.p: What Trick, thou baffled Armour-Bearer? What Trick, I say? Speak or I'll—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, Cousin, I'll quit Mrs. Philadelphia, and Court Mrs. Isabella; and is not that just such a Trick?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: For all your Fury, Mr. Anthony has made good his words, and in a way you cannot be offended at.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Come, come— leave off these Civil Wars, and Unite your Forces to Beleaguer your two Mistrisses, you'll find a tough Siege of it; 'twere therefore fit you began your Approaches.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Right, Mr. Plot, I protest I am on Thorns till I draw up before them, and when I have began my Attacks, if I do not pierce her Bulwark, I'll give her leave to hang me in a Horn-work.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: This Errant Poltrone makes use of so many War-phrases, that I admire they do not fright him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Plot, and Mr. Art, you must help us to meet our fair Enemies; I long to be at the Encounter.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Bravely spoken, my Amorous Mirmidon.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: We'll go and get you the Field of Battel assign'd, then be your Guides to it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: March boldly on, for the Old Proverb's true,
Faint Heart ne'r with Fair Lady had to do. Ex. omnes▪

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: Enter Anthony, Cudden, Plot and Art.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: WEll Gentlemen, we have got the Ladies to give you audience, and now be sure to ply them close.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: Teach your Father to get Children! Instruct me in the affairs of Love! 'Slid, do you think I have learnt Ovid de arte Amandi for nothing?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: That's pretty in faith; make Love by Book! Buz Mr. Tony, if ever you get a Mistress, I'll be content to lose mine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How the Ignorant will always reproach the Learned; Why I tell you Kinsman Cudden, But for my Civility to you I wou'd now have had a Couple.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Civility to me? do not Christen the Child by a wrong name. If you do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Marry come up Don Cudden: for by your Rodomantado's, you should be a Castilian; Left me, did you say? Know, I scorn your leavings! You only named your own Mistress, and I discovered to you, who was mine.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Tony, take heed, wake not a sleepy Lyon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lyon? an Essex one then, and without a White-face too, nay, since you whet me so, I must tell you all the little advantages thou thoughtst to have got over me, were by Treacheries: Yes, I'le draw your verbal portraiture; you are one that will speak a man fair to his Throat, and cut his Face behind his back.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Thou Slanderer of thy own flesh and blood; take that for thy Lye. offers to strike, and Plot and Art hold him.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Hold, hold, why this heat?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I heard nothing from Mr. Antony that might offend you Mr. Cudden.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Why? did you not hear him say, I would speak a man fair to his Face, and cut his Throat behind his back.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, Marry did I not, I appeal to these Gentlemen, what, say you Sirs?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: He only said you would speak a man fair to his Throat, and cut his Face behind his back.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Which was, indeed, the Anagram of what you imagin'd he said.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Hey-day! What new word is that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well Cousin, I forgive you, you see now in your own case, how Impartial a man you are.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: 'Slid affront me again? take that. offers to strike, but is stopt.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Death! Did you not hear him call mean Impartial man to my face? you had best turn that into an Angaram too.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: 'Tis past my skill I assure you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And pray angry Kinsman what would you have said, if I had called you a partial man?

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: putting his finger in his mouth. There I was a little out of the way— pox on your hard words, they turn my brain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis well! I am not as Chollerick as you, here would have been a foul house then,

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Yes, of your making.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: For shame do not thus discompose your selves; when you are going to Court your Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: They may think you ill humour'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come then, shew us the way to them: as much as I love fighting; for this once, I had rather assault my Mrs. than my Kinsman: farwel the warlike brow; Cudden Ile now put on my Halcion face.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: What's that Halcion face Mr. Art? is it any thing that savours of affronting me?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: No, no, nothing of that Nature, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: This is the door— I'le knock— Exeunt. he knocks.

div.stage: The Scene opens, Philadelphia and Isabella appear with their Hoods over their Faces. Nan and Nell. Cudden runs to Philadelphia and Antony to Isabella, whom they lead by the Hand on the Stage.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Madam, I come to lay my Heart to your Feet.

sp.speaker: Phila.
sp.p: At mime?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Yes, yours Madam: I do not use to Eat my words.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Are you not mistook Mr. Cudden?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: 'Slid I doubt I am; but how shall I retreat?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As I am an Heir Madam, I am come to you on the like honourable Employment.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Sure Mr. Antony you take me for my Sister.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: By the Mass that were pretty; what? mistake my Mistress? do you think we are playing at Blindmans-Buff.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why, who do you think I am?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As if the palpitation of my Amorous Heart did not whisper in my Ear, you are the Conqueror of it Mrs. Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: If you will not trust me, vouchsafe to trust your own Eyes. She pulls up her hood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha! a pox of this Heart of mine, that must be panting after the wrong Petticoat; I'le make it keep Lent for this Impertinent Rampantness, Cudden too will beat me: Kinsman we must counter-march, take the better for the worse, and resign me up my Richer for Poorer, I had like, by a meer mistake, to have beaten up thy Quarters, while thou wer't beating up mine.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Soft Sir, 'tis not my custom to be so inconstant, since Fortune has flung me on this beautiful Lady, here I'le fix: Face about Tony, and as you were.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Very fine, and pray what did we fight our four Duels for this Morning: Have you forgot our Capitulations; as I take it they were not as you expound them now.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: If thou lik'st not my Exposition, a word to the Wise, you know how to write, where I dwell, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well! go thy ways; thou art the first man that I ever saw choose to play at Hab-nab for a Wife; at least let's Shuffle the Cards again.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: No Sir, 'tis a sign that you have the worst game, when you offer to deal again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is this then your Median and Persian-like resolution?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: More, this is the resolution of a Lover, and before all these wittnesses.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Cudden I have over-reach'd you, worse then when I came with Bow and Arrows against your Case of Cudgels: For I was necessited when you said you were in Love with Mrs. Isabel, to seem joyful at it, and to declare my Mistress was Mrs. Philadelphia; when all the while I protest my Heart was ready to fly in the Face of my Tongue, for telling such an Egregious, Monstrous and Detestable Lye; therefore with blyth Countenance and merry Glee, thus I turn to my happiness, and leave you to your misery: By this light Mrs. Isabel I was always in Love with you, and you only.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: What? Do you think after so much Inconstancy, and before of many witnesses of it, I'le accept you for my Gallant; you may go whistle after a Mistress for me.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Ha! ha! I could almost fall in Love with Mrs. Isabel for this witty Justice of hers; Tony, thus I turn to my happiness, and leave you to your misery.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: You are exceedingly mistook Mr. Cudden, even as much as Esquire Tony, do not I know you fought for my Sister, and your mistake flung you upon me: I must be gain'd by merit not by chance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Cudden, methinks your Mistress is somewhat witty in her Justice too: Commend me to Constancy in a Lover: You are likely to have a Campania to Exercise that Vertue in.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Do not jeer me, for if thou dost, I'le wreak my Anger on thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Methinks we need not fall upon one another, while each of us has an Enemy to deal with: Come let's rather make one brave Charge, and try to recover the day.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Agreed, Mrs Philadelphia, I will not be deny'd, you must except me for your Sweet-heart She turns from him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Cudden, pursue your point, and the Victory will be yours infallibly; for you
have already made her turn her back— pretty Mrs. Isabel, behold a Wandring-Pilgrimical Heart begging an Alms at the gate of your Love; if you drive it from thence without relief 'twill dye by the way: And I'le lay the death of the poor thing at your door; Consider whether you had rather be haunted with my person, or by my Ghost; for one of them cannot be avoided— Isab. smiles

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Tony continue this way of pleading; you see it takes exceedingly; by her Smiling at all you said; pray which is better, to have a Mistress turn a backside to her Lover, or Laugh at him to his Face; these are our two lamentable Cases.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Nay Ladies, now you deal too Tyrannically with your Lovers.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Their fault indeed is great, but not unpardonable; for they have been more unfortunate than guilty, since you had not only your Hoods over your Faces; but you had exchang'd Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'twas those damn'd Hoods and Petticoats, as Mr. Plot very truly observes, made us run into our mistakes; therefore 'twould be hard, if we should loose your favour because we cannot see through Taffety.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: No Judge in England wou'd condemn us, for not doing Impossibilities:

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Nay, if you do not Pardon Penitent Lovers, 'tis pitty but you should Marry hard Hearted ones.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You two I find are Brib'd for your Friends; but yet to show you we will not be Judges and parties, wee'l appeal to the Sentence of Mrs. Mall, and Mrs. Nan.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay, and stand to it too.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: So will I— (aside) If I like it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will be bound by it Hand and Foot, only my pretty Judges remember, if you lay wrong Foundations the thing cannot stand long.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I accept the power.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Silence! Hear the Court.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: I decree all past mistakes shall be forgiven and forgotten, and the Squires shall now choose which each of them will give Chace too.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But if they change again, my Sentence is, they shall be Hang'd for Currs.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: I protest I never saw at an Assize, more quick and Equal Justice Administred.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You may talk of your Cooks, your Crocks and Ploudens, but Mrs. Nans, and Mrs. Nells Reports for my Money.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Silence! hear the Court out: I also order that each of them shall make an Extempore Stanza, to her he declares for.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Take notice of that Iack, 'twas purely as I am a Lover in my favour, for Cudden will assoon make a pair of Iapan Boots as a Stanza.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: to Art whispering Tom, as thou lov'st me prepare a Stanza, and whisper it my Ear, that it may pass for one of my making.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I also Sentence these two Lovers this Night on pain of loosing their Mistresses to give them a Serenade under their Windows, and a Crotesk or Burlesk.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Now cannot I tell what the meaning of Crotesk or Burlesk is; sure they are Law Terms.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Cousin, do not discover your Ignorance: I'le interpret to you anon what's the meaning of those two hard words, do you send Trick to get the Musick and their Boys that Dance the Jiggs, and leave the rest to my managing.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: I'le undertake that, or lay the blame on me.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: You like our Sentence I hope and will conform to it.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: 'Tis a hard one, but we will obey.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Since our promises are past we are bound.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Tony, I'le name first.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thank you for that.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Why, the She Judges have order'd that each shall choose whom he Loves best, and I must have the preference, for I got the Day in Duel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lord! What an Un-mathemattical Head you have: How a duce can I choose if you choose first: For then I must take what you leave, and that would be a fine Choice: I'le have Mrs. Betty, and Mrs. Nan expound their own Act.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: whispers. Hark ye Tony! A word in your Ear; let me choose or I'le beat thee as black as my Mistress Eyes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What say you Ladies, methinks my Kinsman has whisper'd in my Ear a very good proposal: 'Tis that we shall draw Lots who shall first choose.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Content, content!

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Another word in your Ear: forswear what thou hast said or I'le Bastinadoe thee to Mummy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why do you whisper so, you need not be asham'd of your proposal, 'tis as equal a one as the former and shows a pretty variety in you Invention; for he offers that Mrs. Philadelphia and Mrs. Isabel should determine our difference, to which I consent:

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Tony, another word in your ear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What, more Proposals? This comes of commending the fertility of your contriving Noddle. Why, I tell you, we all are satisfy'd in it, and 'tis superfluous to give more testimonies of it; adone, adone, I say.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: I must, and will speak to you again. Takes Ant. apart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, I am loath to deny you any thing.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Yield me the preference, or with hand and foot I'll affront thee instantly before all the Company.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: whispers. Who would you choose?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Mrs. Isabel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now Ladies, we have sav'd you the pains of ending our Dispute, we have done it our selves; I chose, and for ever dedicate my heart to Mrs. Philadelph.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Why, what an Impudent Fellow art thou to say thou chosest?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, is not Mrs. Isabel your Mistress? Deny it if thou dar'st. You all see I scorn whispering, I am for open dealing in Affairs of Love. Come, come, your Stanza, Cudden.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Yes, yes, your Stanza!

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: to Isab. Madam, I choose you, and left your Sister to Anthony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your Stanza, I say; in that I'll allow you the preference, beacuse I have it in this. Come, come; alack, how long you are Studying: Verses must come easily.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Tom, art thou ready?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Not yet, but I will instantly.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Give me a tugg as the signal, when you are prepared.— No— Cousin, you shall begin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sweet Cousin! That honour shall be yours. I will never be out-done by you in Civility.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Nay, nay, you are the Scholar, and therefore should lead the way.— Are you ready yet, Tom?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Almost.—

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: 'Slid, make haste or I shall be disgrac'd. Come, Anthony, methinks your Muse is somewhat Hide-bound; art thou ready yet?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Within a moment I shall.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, no, my Muse is only civil, and desires to let that Stranger, Madam, your Muse, go before her Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Not yet, Tom! 'Tis a damnable long moment.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I protest, Cousin, I will not versifie before you; remember I have sworn first.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: hems three times, spits as often, then says. Now Tom, or never! Mrs. Isabel, will you be pleas'd to stand out, that I may make my approaches to you without Interruption?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Well, Sir! I obey you! Now your Verses.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: to Art. Not yet?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Immediately.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: I have got such an Impertinent Rheum. Hems and spits.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sure, Mrs. Philadelph, my Cousin has some great Imagination, for I see 'tis like to choak him in bringing it up.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Hey-day, I think you have a design to affront me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, no, I leave that Office to your Verses to do for me.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Blest Relief! Both for me and Tony, Art plucks Cudd. by the sleeve. for I had no way left to wheedle away the time one moment longer, but to fall foul on him. Now, Mrs. Isabel, listen to the Virginity of my Muse. Art is to whisper. the Stanza line by line to Cudd. who is to repeat it after him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I listen, Mr. Cudden, but methinks you are long a falling on.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: to Plot. I would not have had such a dry bob from my Mistress; no, not to have been the Author of Orlando Furioso.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.l: I like you so very well,
That my Love no longer can tarry;
If we do not instantly Marry.
How do you like this Stanza, Tony?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty double Stanza, for two of you spoke it.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Mr. Cudden, let me advise you to get a great Cold, and give it your Prompter, that he may be sure to whisper softlier.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I hope, Mr. Cudden, your Musick anon, and your Dancing, will be as good as your Verses.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Madam, no Musick in the World like the Trill of a smooth Madrigal.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now, Mrs. Philadelphia, give ear; and you, my two fair Judges, hearken whether I perform your Sentence Catagorically. Stand off, I say, I need no Prompter, though you did. Cudden goes near Anthony▪

lg.l: [Hems thrice.] Bright Mrs. Philadelph,
I love none but your self:
And if you love me at that rate,
Without ever tarrying
For that dull thing call'd Marrying,
We'll fall to the Effects of it strait.

sp.p: Cudden was affraid, forsooth, to lye with his Mistress, till the Parson had conjur'd them into one Bed; but I offer mine the civility of a Fornication, as a Prologue to the Play.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: No marry, Sir, was I not affraid, and if yet Mrs. Isabel will walk a turn alone with me in the Garden, I will present her with a Green-Gown, without staying for the help of a man in a Black Gown to do it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pish! This is after I put you in mind of it; and besides, you offer'd it to her in dull Prose. Now let Judge Mall, Nell, and Justice Nan, determine whose Stanza was the best.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Mr. Cudden's was the most civil, and Mr. Anthony's the most Amorous.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mr. Cudden shew'd most Discretion, and Mr. Anthony most Mettle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hang Discretion in Love, Mettle is the Vertue there; a Discreet Passion is a Bull.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: What Calf is that? Call a discreet passion a Bull?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: No Quarrelling, Mr. Cudden, your Kinsman is a merry man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And so wou'd he be too, if he were not a sad fellow.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Mr. Anthony, we leave you and Mr. Cudden to prepare Musick and Dancers; for if, you fail of giving us those Entertainments precisely at ten this Night, Bonos Nochios to your Loves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And Bonos Nochios to the World, whenever you bid such a good Night to my Passion. Ex. Women, Art and Plot.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: What! Do you think I'll fail my Mistresses Assignment? That were pritty i'faith. Come, Tony, we'll go send Trick to engage our Fiddles.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Else our Sweet-hearts will be devilishly out of Tune. Ex. Ambo.

div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy, his Lady, Pedagog and Winifred.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Move me! No, I am resolved nothing shall alter me; two such Rich Heiresses may not, nor shall not be lost by my Son and Nephew, I can hamper their Estates if they are stubborn.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Would my two Nieces had Isabel and Philadelphia's Estates, or they two had my Nieces humours.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Alas, they now jeer them so sensibly, and the Gallants bear it so patiently, that I lose my temper.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: If Love were ever blind he is so in Mr. Antony and Mr. Cudden: Why Madam I tell you they have no feeling; and therefore why should they pretend to be Lovers; besides I saw Trick and the two gibing Damsels close in Consultation, and when I surpriz'd them at it, they started as if they had seen a Ghost, and immediately vanished.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: This After-noon.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: That Trick Sir has his Name from his Nature: And I more than suspect he is a Pensioner to Mr. Plot and Mr. Art.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I have long doubted it.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Nay, you may be sure of it, if you watch him this Night as a Cat does a Mouse; for by my Modesty, some design is ripe to be Executed, in which he has at least a finger, and therefore, Sir, let us separate our selves the better to discover.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I like Goody Winifred's Advice; Wife let us take our Quarters in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Agreed! For methinks I smell some Roguery. Ex. Sir Tim. at one door. and his Lady at another: Ped. offers to go out, but is stopt by Winifred.

sp.speaker: G. Win.
sp.p: Soft, Doctor Amorous! I have only dismist the Knight and his Madam, that I might read your Worship a Curtain-Lecture without Interruption.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: My Reverend Chuck! What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Lord! How ignorant you seem! Have you forgot you said you would put in a good deed to serve my Lady? Was that a Sacerdotal Expression?

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: What a Critick Jealousie makes a Passionate Lover? By my Dotage on those pritty Pig-nies of thine, I meant no hurt; let that solemn vow suppress thy doubts.

sp.speaker: G. Win.
sp.p: How Equivocally your Speech is Phras'd; perhaps you think, having two strings to your Bow in affairs of Concupiscence, is no harm.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Concupiscence!

sp.speaker: G. Win.
sp.p: Yes, Concupiscence! Does that term of Art fright you?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: All my Concupiscence is confin'd within thy Parish.

sp.speaker: G. Win.
sp.p: But how few Parsons are there that do not covet double Benefices?

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: None do, when they have in one more than they can turn to; and that I'll be Depos'd I have in thine, But to convince thee by other Evidences, that thou art the Mistress of my Heart, I'll trust thee with a secret which I would not confess to my Ghostly Father.

sp.speaker: G. Win.
sp.p: What is it, my Dapper- Domine?

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Why, Sir Timothy is smitten, and has made me his Love-Ambassador.

sp.speaker: G. Win.
sp.p: That is his Pimp! A Reverend Employment for one of your Cassock.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Nay, I am satisfy'd his is a Platonick Flame; there's no more heat in it, than old rotten Wood that shines.

sp.speaker: G. Win.
sp.p: But that Wood laid on the fire will burn; and who knows but his may do the like, when his Mistresses eyes kindle it. But what's her Name?

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: 'Tis even Mrs. Betty.

sp.speaker: G. Win.
sp.p: 'Slid, that mad Wench will put him into more shakings and burnings than an Ague: For old men to desire to see their Unkles is Natural, but to desire to see their Nieces is Prodigious.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: However, be silent in the business; leave me to improve it, and if we two do not get more by it than the Lover and his Damosel, say I am no Witch.

sp.speaker: G. Win.
sp.p: Presto be gone! Here's Tony and Cudden; we must not be seen together, they will discover our Amours. Ex.

div.stage: Enter Anthony and Cudden.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am glad at heart that Trick has engag'd the Musick and their Jigg-Boys, for in this merry time, 'tis two to one they had been bespoken by others.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Kinsman; though they had been bespoken by Men, Women and Children, yet I would have unbespoken them again, though it had cost me twenty Duels. What did not I undertake to bring them at the hour, and to the place? And when I am once engaged in a business, fall back, fall edge, I will go through stitch with it.

div.stage: Enter Trick hastily.

sp.speaker: Trick,
sp.p:
Oh Sir! The Musick and their Dancing-Boys, as I was conducting them hither, were seiz'd on by a Cast of young Gallants, who swore top Top-gallant-high, That if they did not come along with them, they would spit them on the place; and as an earnest of it, drew their Tucks, and fell a slashing among us, worse than two
Back-Sword-Fencers, and drove the Fiddlers before them like a Flock of Geese.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Anthony, for this affront they shall lose their Lives.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But alas Cousin! we shall lose what's worse to us, (viz.) Mrs. Philadelphia and Mrs. Isabel.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Thou sawcy Clown! how durst thou put thy Mistresses name before mine? I could find in my heart to begin my dire Revenge on thee, and so proceed to the end of the Chapter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lord how quarrelsome you are: is it not natural for a Lover to name his Mistress first.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: to Trick. Why didst thou not tell them they were bespoke for me?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I did! but alack-a-day, would I had not, for they beat me the more rufully.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Beat thee!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But after they said they were sorry.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: O, did they so! that qualifies.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But 'twas because it was not your Worship, whom they said they had much rather have lurry'd than me.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: I scorn so much as to enquire after the Names or Lodgings of such insolent Puppies.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nay, they added, they knew your Worship had as ill an Ear in Musick, as a mangy Brewers Horse, that then by accident was passing by.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. Antony on my life the Rogues were drunk: That ridiculous Comparison has converted my rage into laughter. 'Tis a strange thing Cousin, what diverse effects Wine produces in men; some it turns to Apes, some to Lyons, some to Elephants, and some to Bully-Rocks, of which latter sort our Fiddler-stealers are; and so for the present I let them pass. But mark what follows, for I am a kind of Prophet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So am I too Cousin; and I prophesie we shall lose our Mistresses; you know the Sentence of the Court, and you undertook to get the Musick and Jigg-boys, or else you bid me lay the blame on you; which by my defeated hopes I will; it will be a comfort however when I can safely swear that I lost my Mistress by your fault, and not my own; for gone she is I know: since 'tis impossible to recover a set of Scrapers before ten, for 'tis now half an hour past nine.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Anthony, things are not yet so desperate, for just now I saw three men pass by with long Cloaks, and my Eyes deceiv'd me if I did not see a glimpse of some Instruments under them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This Intelligence has some life in it: But how a dickings shall we do for a Jigg?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: A Jigg! that's pretty! why I tell thee Kinsman, I never saw Wake or Fair, that I did not out-Jigg all the men at it; the Women too being the Judges: But that which troubles me most is, who shall dance the Dances with the two hard names— pox ont, I forget what you call them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The Crotesk and Burlesk-Dances.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Yes, yes those damn'd Crabbed names will never sink into my pericranium.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why those are only French names for Jiggs.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Why here it is! is it not enough that we have our Laws, the names of our Meats, and Drinks, and our Diseases French, but we must have our Dances too, I tell you `tis abominable.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But Sir, the Crowders I told you of will be gone out of sight.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Away Trick, and keep them at Bay till we come up.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Tell them we'll give them double pay; that is, if you cannot win them with single.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Hallow to us when you have boarded them, and we'll bear up to you. Ex.

div.stage: Enter Isabella, Philadelphia, Nell and Nan, in the Balcony, Plot and Art.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Has Trick play'd his part as we directed it?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I think he has done it more dexterously, and all things take above expectation.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How long will it be e'er the two Squires come?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Just as long as our Serenade and Dances will take up, for we have Calculated all things to a moment.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If your Musick be ready call them in, for Suitors are Impatient, and may be here before their hour.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: And I think, that not only the Fiddles speak better than the Squires, but also, that the Heads of the Base-Viols are handsomer than the Faces of those two Lovers: Call them in then, I pray.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I'll do you the service. Art, at the door, bids them come in.

div.stage: Enter Musick and Dancers.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Will you have a merry Song, or a sad one?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: We'll have the last Song which Mr. Plot made on his own heart.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I assure you, Van Dyck never drew more to the Life than Mr. Plot has done in that Piece.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: 'Tis a new way of Painting, for I drew two Pictures at once. I hope, Madam, hearts that are so like, cannot choose but love one another.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Hope is free, Mr. Plot.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: And so should Hearts be, if all were as Wise as mine:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Come, come, the Song, the Song.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: SInce you will needs my heart possess,
'Tis just to you I first confess
The Faults to which 'tis given;
It is to change much more inclin'd
Than Women, or the Sea or Wind,
Or ought that's under Heaven.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Nor will I hide from you this Truth,
It has been from its very youth
A most egregious Ranger;
And since from me it often fled,
With whom it was both born and bred,
'Twill scarce stay with a Stranger.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: The black, the fair, the gay, the sad,
Which made me often fear 'twas mad,
With one kind look could win it;
So naturally it loves to range,
That it has left success for change,
And what's worse, Glories in it.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Often when I am laid to rest,
'Twould make me act like one possest,
For still 'twill keep a pother;
And though you only I esteem,
Yet it will make me in a Dream
Court and Enjoy another.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: And now if you are not affraid,
After these truths that I have said,
To take this Arrant Rover;
Be not displeas'd, if I protest,
I think the Heart within your Breast
Will prove just such another.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I find 'twill be a hard matter to hold such a slippery piece of flesh:

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: But the greater honour, Madam, is yours that have done it.
Art to Phil. My Heart, Madam, is the very Antipodes to Mr. Plot's; for I first gave it to you, and 'twould never since so much as pant after another, though you have us'd it most unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Phil▪
sp.p: Some Hearts are of the Nature of Spaniels, the more you beat them, the more they'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: But then you must show them Game often, else they will go after others that will.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Dancing is better than talking, at least, as you two do.— The Dance, the Dance. They Dance Antick Dances. When that is done, a noise is made within; he looks within the Scene.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What noise is that? Ladies away; and you must resign your places to better Company. To the Fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Away, away. Women step a little back in the Balcony. Ladies, since we have made the Play, you will allow us a Room in your Box to see it. Musick and Dancers go off instantly.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Silence is consent. Ex. Art and Plot, who go up to the Balcony:

div.stage: Enter three Men with long Cloaks.

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: They still follow us.

sp.speaker: 2 d.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and now 'tis time to let them overtake us.

sp.speaker: 3 d.
sp.p: 'Tis so, for we are under the Balcony.

div.stage: Enter Trick.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Stand, Friends! I charge you in Mr. Cudden's Name to make a halt, and draw up till he comes. He hollows.

div.stage: Enter Cudden and Anthony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But what if they should not be Fiddlers, and thinking to Hunt a Hare, we should find it a Bear.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p:
'Slight, thou art the Cowardly'st Fellow in Hell: What! Do you think I
do not know a Fiddler from a Hector? I take the business on my self, and that's Insurance enough for you, Squire Tony.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh, are you come Sir? I have kept them at Bay till you came in view, and now my part is done. Ex. Trick.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Come, Friends, you much march along with me; we'll pay you for your pains.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, marry must you; ours is a business of Love, to which all other affairs must strike Sail.

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, what do you take us for?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Come, leave off your fooling; do not we know what you are? Why, I tell you, you have Fiddlers Faces on your Shoulders, and Violins under your Cloaks.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This is only to heighten the price of your hire; but no catching old Birds with Chaff.

sp.speaker: 2 d.
sp.p: We are no Fiddlers, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I know you would be call'd Musicians; I commend your Modesties, but I see you have tunable Faces, I read Mi, Fa, Sol, in the very looks of you.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Come, come, be not asham'd of your Profession; it is an honest and a merry one.

sp.speaker: 3 d.
sp.p: Are not you merry, Gentlemen, to perswade us to own a Trade we never were bound unto?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, I say, lay aside your Grimaces, and your Fiddle-faddles, for on the Reputation of Souldiers, we'll pay you Heliogabilus-like.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: 'Slight, you would be Courted would you? Come, say you will play, or Ill so Bumfiddle your ribs—

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: Nay, we'll say any thing rather than be beaten.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Oh, have we brought you a Note lower; go Anthony, and call under the Window.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: under the Balcony. Mrs. Philadelphia, Mrs. Isabella, here are your Serenaders; come with half a File of Crowders: Open your Casements, receive Harmony from us, and give light to us. Philad. and Isab. appear.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: O, Mr. Anthony! Long look'd for comes at last; but where are your Musicians and your Dancers? What made you stay so late?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Troth, Madam, I gave our Musicianers so much Money to drink your Health, that having thereby elevated their Spirits, they fell out, challeng'd one another, fought on the spot with their Instruments, broke them, and their Heads with them, and had thereby broken my heart by their disappointment, had not my Cousin Cudden and I, by dint of Arms, forc'd these three Gamesters from six Gentlemen, who were glad, at last, to fly away Swearing and ill Edify'd.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Those do not look like Musicians.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: They are then better than they look.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Observe, I pray, have they not Strike up Faces?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But where are the Dancers?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: We two are the Dancers.

sp.speaker: 2 d.
sp.p: Ladies, we are no Fiddlers, but these Gentlemen having Tippled a Note above Ela, would therefore beat us into a Confession that we are.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Nay then, by my life, set me a Dancing with your Instruments, or I'll set you a Dancing with mine. Listing up his Cane.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, my Friends! Uncloak, Uncloak.

sp.speaker: 3 d.
sp.p: We shall catch cold then.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.p: A Pottle of Mull'd Sack will cure you, and you shall have enough to buy a Gallon.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Come, I'll take away your Inchanted Garments which make you thus resty, for I long to be Dancing. Cudd. and Ant. fling open the three mens Cloaks, who instantly present their Pistols cock'd at their Breast.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Quarter, Quarter.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Save my life, and do with me what you will.

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: The only Tune we can play, is, Deliver your Purse, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here, worthy Gentlemen, I am glad I have it to pleasure you with.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: What's the matter, Mr. Anthony? 'Tis not the fashion to pay the Musick before they have plaid.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Slid, Madam, do you not see what a Trick they have plaid already? Besides, these are Pistoleer-Musicians, and will be paid when ever they ask it.

sp.speaker: 2 d.
sp.p: to Cudd. Sir, you that so long to Dance should empty your Pockets first! Oh, it will make you trip so lightly.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Ladies, will you not raise the House for our Rescue?

sp.speaker: 3 d.
sp.p: Stir not, else we'll shoot you.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: Alas, we dare not discover the favour we did you to receive your visits so late▪

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.l: A Curse on the favour— there— Flings a Purse.
May it bring you to Tyburn▪

sp.speaker: 3 d.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, we must then have your Vests, Tunicks, Sashes, Silk▪ stockings, and Bevers.

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: Nay, and your Periwiggs too, which are of more worth than your Heads: The Thatch is better than the House it covers.

sp.speaker: 2 d.
sp.p: Flea, flea, quickly, for though your Mistresses think you are but Geese, yet we'll show them you are Foxes, for we value your Cases more than your Carkasses.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Worthy Musicians of the Fire-Arms, do not expose our Nakedness to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: You are a sweet Lover, that would hide your secrets from your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ah! If it were to her alone I would discover all; but you have not us'd us so Courteously, I take it, as that I should have the like Inclination to disclose my secrets to you.

sp.speaker: Second
sp.p: to Cudd. Sit down my Eleven-pence-half-penny Squire, that I may strip you for the Jigg you so long to dance.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Alas! Gentlemen! I am out of my Dancing-humour, nor did I ever yet practice to Dance Naked.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Wee'l teach you: You took us for Fiddlers, but you shall find we are Dancing-Masters.

sp.speaker: Second
sp.p: to Ant. Come, Esquire of the doleful Face, we must put you into your Calfs-skin-habit, 'tis a pretty and a new dress for an Ante-mask. They strip Ant. who often casts up many a sad look to the Balcony, and Cudd. does the like.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are the first Dancing Masters that ever came to teach their Scholars, and brought Iron Fiddles with them.

sp.speaker: 3 d.
sp.p: Oh, we are High-way Musicians.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But I am for the Town Musicians, they are civiller bred, and though they pick our Pockets, yet 'tis in a genteeler way.

sp.speaker: 3 d.
sp.p: to Cudd. Nay, Shirt and all; what you swear to your Mistresses will then be believ'd, for Truth is like a Virgin, most moving when Naked.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: Gentlemen, let us interceed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Methinks you have been long about it, had you staid a minute longer, you could have interceeded for nothing but our Hides; all the rest is gone.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, for our sakes spare their Shirts.

sp.speaker: 3 d.
sp.p: Well, Ladies, for your sakes we will, allow us to press you to Dance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In my sight, and I forgive you your having stript me in theirs.

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: We cannot come at them, else we would do you that Courtesie— away, away.

div.stage: Ex. the three and the Musick.

sp.speaker: Plil.
sp.p: You are very kind, Mr. Anthony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I would you were so too, Mrs. Philadelphia; I was only Ambitious to have the same Ante-Taylors put you into my Livery. Love is a Race, and since I am stript for it, I would have had you the like, for I hate Advantages.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: But who put you on these Robbers for Musicians?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas Physiognomist Cudden, he knew them, he said, to be Fiddlers, by their Viol de Gambo Faces, and so confidently inveigled me into the like Error, that I should have taken them for High Priests sooner than High-way Men; remember too 'twas he undertook to bring the Musick.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Leave off upbraiding me, or by this fist I'll thump you with it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Cudden, by my Troth you did embark poor Mr. Anthony in this Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Law you there Cudden, your own Mistress being Judge condemns you: I have often told you, that you had not Guts enough in your brain to make a Fiddle-string, and now Exce signum, you have put us in a very pleasant Figure to Court Ladies in.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: I dare say never Wooers yet appear'd in such a Garb before their Sweet-hearts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And all this is the Product of your unfertile Noddle. Nay, I must be thought a Eool for keeping your wise Campany.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Why, you Puppy, did you not say you saw Mi, Fa, Sol, in their looks, and that they had Strike up Faces; confess all this, or I'll Cuff thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Cuff me! Thou Ignoramus in Folio.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Ignoramus in thy face, and this to boot. Kicks him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, since we have only our Puris Naturalibus-Weapons to sight with.— have at you— Ladies, he promis'd you a Serenade and fail'd, but I promis'd you no Prize, and yet will play one. They fall a Cuffing.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: Well fought Mr. Anthony.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Rarely Cuff'd Mr. Cudden.

div.stage: Enter Constable and Watch.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: What noise is that? Knock them down both, 'tis the shortest way to keep the Protectors Peace. The Watch seize on them. Away with those Quarrelling Drunkards, and put them in the Cage.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: By this light, had we not been parted, I would have beaten better manners into that dull Pericranny of thine.— Kick me before my Mistriss!

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: As soon as I am out of Captivity, I'll kick thee Front, Rear, and Flanks, before all the Mistresses in Europe.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: Away, away with them, and put into the Cage those prating Tipplers in Frocks.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: as the haul him out. Nay, though I be torn in pieces, I will take a civil leave of my Mistress; that will I, though Cudden has not the manners or the courage to do it.

lg.l: Since for your sake, me in the Cage they fling,
Even in that Cage your Praises I will sing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: 'Twill make a pritty Canary Bird there.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Let's away, for now all the Farce is done. Ex. Omnes.

div.head: ACT. V.
div.stage: Enter Anthony, Cudden, Plot and Art; the two first buttoning their Vests.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: YOU see, for your sakes we have shook hands.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What damnable Hypocrites and Cheats your Birds in Cages are, for they keep a leaping and singing as if they were ravish'd for joy at their condition; when for my part, by the experiment I have lately had of a Cage, I think it one of the Melancholy'st Habitations I know, but Hell.— But how did you recover our spoils from those Dragoons which Plunder'd us of them?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: We heard by chance, in an Ale-house, as we were passing by, three men talking to Mr. Cudden, and Mr. Anthony, and how handsomly they had robb'd and stripp'd them, which made us break into the low room, where they were drinking their own Healths at your Costs, and seizing on their Pistols, crying out Thieves, Thieves, they fled.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: But left behind their Booty, which as we were carrying home to you, we found you in the Cage, and so releas'd and cloath'd you.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: 'Twas kindly and luckily done.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, if ever I press men with long Cloaks for Fiddlers, till I see they have no Pistols under them, may they fire them all at this Heir-apparent Head of mine.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: But how were the Ladies entertain'd?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Better than we I am sure on't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, better than they have deserv'd, for they had no more fellow-feeling of our Misfortunes, than the Watch had, till your half piece mollify'd those Bears with two feet.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Well, I'll leave you, since for my part I am ready to freeze, and must thaw my Heart with some Spanish Juice. Tom, wilt go with me to the Mermaid?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Can you doubt, that I, who forsook you not in the Cage, will leave you going to the Tavern?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Tony! Be sure my Uncle and his Family know nothing of this Intrigue.

div.stage: Ex. Cudd. and Art.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am Gagg'd, I warrant you. Enter Betty and Nan.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p:
Mr. Anthony, we have all this morning been seeking you and Mr. Cudde;
there is such a Vacarme in your Fathers House, that the noise of a Navy Royal, tho in a Hurricane, and on a Lee-shore, is still Musick to it, for Sir Timothy and my Aunt, have heard all your Pranks.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Which has so exasperated your Father and my Lady, that you are forbidden the House, and a Lawyer and Scrivener are sent for Post haste, to draw up a new Settlement, to Disinherit you, and to Intail his Estate on Mr. Nicholas, your younger Brother.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well-a day, and Woe is me: A pox on Love. Dear Mrs. Betty, advise and pitty a poor and miserable Disinherited Heir and Lover.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Nay, the Judgment for 3000 l. which Sir Timothy had on his Nephew Cuddens Estate, he has now Sworn, and kneeling taken the Oath, that he will never release, but extend it forthwith.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hang Cudden, 'twas he drew me into this Periclitamine I am now ingulf'd into; he must forsooth be a Physiognomist, with a curse to him, and I must be such a Nicodemus as to rely on his Skill, when the Puppy has no more knowledge in him than there is in a Roasted Apple. I am, you say, prescrib'd and banish'd, and must live at Rovers; nor have a penny in my Pocket to buy a Tavern Cordial with.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Mr. Anthony, I have always been your Friend, and therefore lament your condition; take this Purse for your present supply. She gives him a Purse.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This kindness, pritty Mrs. Betty, from one of your Sex, I protest, does half reconcile me to all of it; for till now, I never got any thing from a Female but a Clap.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mr. Plot, will you help me to seek out Mr. Cudden, he needs Intelligence and Relief too.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Will not it be scandalous to leave your Sister alone with Mr. Anthony?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No, I warrant you, the hours of affliction drive out loose thoughts.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Then, Mrs. Nan, I am ready to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And I'll follow you at your own pace. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But Mrs. Betty, have you so mean a belief of me, as to think 'tis in the power of all the unlucky Stars of Heaven, to cast me down so low, that being alone with you, would not elevate me; I tell you, 'tis an irreparable affront done to the mettle of my Constitution.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Nay then, by this light, Mr. Anthony, I'll leave you. Offers to go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: By those two pritty lights that twinckle in the Sphere of your Skull, but you shall not; you will not make me think you a Fool.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why a fool, pray?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lord! What a ridiculous question you ask, for did ever a handsom Gentlewoman give a distress'd Squire her Purse, but as an earnest that she would give him a better? You know well enough what I mean, a—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Since you make such false Inferences, pray give me back my Purse.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What, part with my Earnest-money, sure you jest.— But Mrs. Betty, to shew you how much your kindness operates on me, I will make you my Confident, and both beg and resolve to rely on your advice, in a most Important Affair. You know I made Election of Mrs. Philadelphia, and Cudden of Mrs. Isabella, and as the Devil would have it, I am told Mrs. Isabel is in Love with me, and Mrs. Philadelphia with Cudden.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh, if this be it, your Intelligencers are Mr. Plot and Mr. Art.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
You say right, for they told us of it as we were returning from the damn'd
Adventure of the Cage, and I am sure neither of them wou'd Trepan us.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: But the truth is Nan and I trepann'd them; for when we saw them come softly behind us to listen to our discourse, and as they thought undiscover'd, we talk'd on purpose that stuff, as some Revenge for their impertinent Curiosity, knowing their great concerns for you.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: Why then 'tis not true.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: No, I assure you; but since you make me the great depository of your Secrets, I will protest to you Philadelphia and Isabella are so far from being in Love with either of you, that they do nothing but Laugh at you both: Nay worse a thousand times; 'tis they which set all the Traps for you both last Night, as I heard them confess this Morning.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: Is this possible?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: 'Tis more, tis certain; so that if you have any mettle show it by your resentment of these affronts.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: Have I then run through so many Herculean labours to be thus Colted; well I see I have brought my Hoggs to a fair market.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Let me alone and I'le order the business so, that if you two will hide your selves an hour hence, behind the Arbour in the Garden; you both shall hear them two not only confess the fact but glory in it.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: If this be so, take my heart for your reward.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Your Heart! why you have already given it to Mrs. Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: Pish I did but only hold forth my Heart to her: But I will give it you without a power of Revocation; in a word you shall have the very intail of my Love: Will that satisfie you?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But will not you prove inconstant? For me thought you were at high, pass, and repass, three times with it last Night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I was then a Juggling, I tell you, and so play'd at Hocus Pocus, and the Babylonian Tooth; but now I am serious.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why then, I will undertake also to make your peace with your Father, and to make him settle 500 l. a year on you for a present Maintenance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If you do, I'll swear you Conjure! But how! How! My Pretty white Witch?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But you must be secret.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As secret as I would keep my Mistresses last favour.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Know then, your Father is in Love with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: With you!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I with me!— And who do you think is his Agent— Even Reverend Mr. Pedagog.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pedagog? That Debauch'd Pupil of mine. I'll whip him with his own Ferula for it; yet he had still a Pimping Physiognomy.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am this morning to give him my last answer, and he shall have it to some purpose; leave this affair to my management, for your advantage. And so farewel; remember an hour hence. Exeunt Betty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I warrant you.— Well, these Women are ticklish things.— How shall I be sure, that she who plays so many tricks to Marry me, will not play me as many tricks after I am Marry'd to her?

div.stage: Enter Cudden.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Tony, have you heard of Sir Timothy's Indignation, and who those were that wheedled us last Night into all our Miseries?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have heard, and am now more troubled to find out a soucing revenge, than at the wrong I have suffer'd.— In the first place, I forswear by Bell, Book, and Candle-light, ever to Couple with Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: And I must tell thee, that Mrs. Nan, who by the way has filch'd from me my heart, by my own consent, has promis'd me too, to bring me to the Hiding-place near the Arbour, where I shall be a Two-Ear-Witness of Mrs. Isabels Confession, which as soon as I have heard, I will take the like Oath as thou hast done; with this Vinegar and Gall addition, that I will less cheerfully Consummate Matrimony with Mrs. Isabella than with a Milch-Cow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But are not we bound in honour, when we hear them abuse us to our faces (though they cannot see us) to make a Sally out of our Ambuscado, and by way of affront and eternal farewel, make an Hebrew Leg to them.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: What a Devil is an Hebrew-Leg? I believe thou hadst a Iew to thy Dancing-Master.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: By the Mass, and he might be one, for he confess'd to me that he suffer'd a Female Circumcision at Paris: But an Hebrew-Congee is when one Marches boldly up to a Woman, and instead of Saluting her, you fetch approwet on your left Toe, and bow your Breech to her, and duck your Head from her Thus, which signifies, Adieu for ever with a Pox to you.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: 'Tis a brave Revenge; but I would do something.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Slid, then let's make them the Rabinical-Congee; for after that there can be no accommodation, 'tis a kind of passing over Rubicon, and cuts off all Treatise of Concord.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Prothee, dear Anthony, instruct me in this hard Word Congee, for the worst affronts to them are the best for us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, thus then: When you have turn'd your back-side to her, you open your Thighs wide, and then clapping your Head between them (an Emblem that the World is turn'd Topsy-turvy with you towards her) you say in a hoarse Tone, fare ill instead of fare wel.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Excellent! For who can be such a Hen-hearted Hypocrite, as to say farewel to one who he detests, and would have fare ill?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Right and Plain-dealing is a Jewel fit for a forsaken Mistresses Ear; besides, your Head being in that Position, it seems as if you spoke through your Breech, which is one of the unfavourest way of uttering ones self to ones Mistress, that can be fancy'd by the Wit or Malice of a Willow-Lover.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: And therefore the fitter usage for such Whirligiggs. Come, let's about it, for the hour is at hand, and I more long to act these Revenges, than ever I did to be Mrs. Isabels Bed-fellow, though without the help of a Parson.

div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy and Pedagogg.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Pedagogg, shall I, or shall I not? Has my burning sighs, dissolv'd the Ice in Mrs. Betty's bosom?

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Consider, Sir, what 'tis for one of your years and relation to be in Love! Pray, Sir, yet listen to my Reasons.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Reasons to a Lover! You may as well hope to alter a High-way-man by Pleading Magna Charta, when he demands your Purse.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: You are fix'd then?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Fix'd as Fate.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, since I cannot alter you, I must tell you I have more than endeavour'd to serve you, for I have three times assaulted Mrs. Betty in your behalf: at the first overture of the business, as the fashion is, she bless'd her self, shriek'd and fled, and gave me a Volly of Injuries at parting.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Has she then Antipathies for me?

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: In a Word, for I know your Worship stands on Thorns, you are immediately to make over that Judgment Irrevocably to Mrs. Betty, who is this Afternoon, at six a Clock, to counterfeit her self sick, and so to retire to her Chamber, ten Minutes before Ienny is to let you in; and as soon as her Lady has flung her self upon the Bed, she will go out, pretending to fetch something for her, and then—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No more, my Ped; thou hast oblig'd me for ever, as an Evidence whereof, here is thy Bond Sign'd and Seal'd. Farewel, excuse a Lovers Impatience.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: But Sir, if my Lady know any thing of this?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hang her, Mouldy Bisket. Ex. several ways

div.stage: The SCENE, a Garden with an Arbour.
Enter Anthony and Cudden hastily.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Slid, they are on our backs already, we must Tappis instantly, or they'll have a view of us.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Let's leap into our Forms; but little do they think how this Ambush will break out upon them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hush! They are come. Enter Isab. Philad. Betty and Nan.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Nay, 'twas too unmercifully done. Why, you could not have us'd them worse had they been your Haters; when, alas, the poor Squires were your passionate Lovers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The truth is, how could men with those Miens expect to be civiller handled?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: They to set up for Heiresses of a 1000 l. a year a piece, with those Coddled Faces.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: whispers to Ant. Tony, that's you she meant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, she abus'd us in Couples, for she said Faces; take your share of the Parboyl'd Visages, I'll rob you of nothing.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Troth methinks Mr. Antony has a pretty fresh Complexion of his own?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Yes, as fresh as Roses after they are still'd.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And for Squire Cudden he has such a Brown-bread look, 'twere enough to make a Plough-man hungry to see him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: to Cudden. Pray Cudden let me have a Slice of your Face to stay my Stomach.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Hold, hold Tony; she'll give you with her Tongue your Belly-full presently.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Come, come, there must be something more than this in the matter; the Men have good Husband-faces; for men are not Marry'd for their Beauties.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: For my part I would not have so much certainty of being nought, as to Marry such a Cuckold-look as Squire Tonys.

sp.speaker: Cudden
sp.p: to Anthony. Mark that Tony!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And mark my Prophesie; if she does not give, who e'er she Marrys, a pair of Horns as big as the Stags of Amboise, may Actaeons Fate be mine.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You saw we took them for Wild Beasts, and so had them Cag'd; and for Squire Cudden, methinks I see an Olio Podrido in his looks; a mixture of Fool, Cuckold, and Surly, three pretty Ingredients to compose the Complexion of a Coventry Lion.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be— Ah, Squire Cudden.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: 'Slight, I can hold no longer, I must Sally; Second me bravely, Tony, and and we'll toss them worse than in Blankets.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If I do not stick to thee in all thou dost attempt, may Philadelphia be my Wife; which is the greatest Imprecation my Chaf'd-brain can invent. They both discover themselves, and come upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Here Mrs. Cow, behold your Calf!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And you, Mrs. Phyly, that fear being a Gamester, should you Wed me, know I am come to bid Defiance to thee to thy face, which is so Warp'd, that 1000 l. a year cannot make it right in my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: And for you, Mrs. Olio Podrido, whenever you have me for your Gallant again, may the Cage you cast me into for one Night, be my Bed-Chamber for ever.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You were such hot Lovers, we had no other Invention to cool you.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: Fruition it self, is not a more Compendious way to quench your flames, than that which our Charity found for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is it so, Mrs. Maukin, with your Antimonial Face? A Face, which now I look on without a Lovers Spectacles, is ready to operate both ways on me: 'Tis a composure of Ialop and Crocus Metallorum-Ana, so that I protest I can hold out no longer; and therefore stand fair, that I may make an Hebrew-Leg.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: Do Mr. Iew.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: An Hebrew-Leg for you too, Mrs. Isabel, with a Rabinical Conge in the Close.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I see they have been better taught, since they were in the Cage, than ever they were by their Dancing-Master: Affliction is an Excellent School. Come on, Practitioners, we'll stand for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That's more than we'll do for you.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Then thus I advance. Making the first Leg agreed upon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The like Civility I pay you, Mrs. Phily, and wish it were worse for your own foure sake.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I protest you never laid out ten Shillings better than on the Constable and his Watch, to teach you these A-la mode Conges.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: Pray Squires give us another Serenade, and let these Legs be made us when you begin the Ball.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Nay, nay, do not commend us till our Ante-mask is done; this is but the first Entry of it. Now for Rabinicus, and let's make them both together.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Content: We will use them Souldier-like, and give them a Volly at parting.

div.stage: They make their Rabinical Conges at once, and both cry, in a boarse voice, Fare-ill for ever, with a Pox to you both.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Bless me! Let's run, they'll fling their Logger-Heads at us else.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Fly, fly, they are Conjuring. Ex. Isab. and Philad shrieking.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Are they gone?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes, yes, with Fleas in their Ears.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A Green-sickness go with them; and may they neither have Chalk nor Lime to feed on.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You have acted the Revenge like men of Italy.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Think to gilt us unpunish'd; but you, Mrs. Nan, have ty'd me for ever to you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am under the same Foot-locks to pretty Mrs. Berty.

div.stage: Enter Trick with two Letters.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir Timothy commanded me, on the peril of my Ears, to deliver this Letter into your own hand, and this into yours, Mr. Anthony. Gives the two Letters.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I tremble to open it, for I know the damn'd Contents of it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Read it boldly, Mr. Anthony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As boldly as I would fight for my Mistress. Reads. Hum, hum Debauch'd like a Ruffian— Fight in the Streets in your Shirts— Caged— disinherited— Your younger Brother all my Estate— And banish you my House for ever.— O! dismal Tidings!

div.stage: Enter Plot and Art.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What in the name of Wonder, have you done to Mrs. Isabel, and Mrs Philadelphia? we met them running and half frighted out of their Wits.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Vowing, with lifted up hands, they will rather marry an Hospital beggar, than either of you.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: And we, two Tinkers Trulls rather than either of them.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Your severe Usage, has made them so kind to us, as to offer us, themselves, for our Wives; if we would Bastinado you, Crop your Ears, and slit your Noses,— for nothing less will pacify them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If I were sure you would be Spirit of Urine-Husbands to them, by this light you should therefore have my consent.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Or were I sure, you would give them incurable Monsieurs, the very first night.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Tis ten to one we shall. Why? Tis the Mode now.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Have you not stinging Letters from Sr. Timothy.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Mine was writ with the Juice of Nettles.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: And mine, with Aqua Infernalis; so that Mr. Plot and Mr. Art, I'm a lost man; my father will disinherit me, for my last nights Gambol, and would disinherit me again, if he could, for Marrying Mrs. Betty, to whom I have dedicated the Triangle of my Breast.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: The Old Usurer has sent to lay on his 3000 l. Judgment on my Estate, with Interest upon Interest, and Cost upon Cost, and Damage upon Damage, so that I doubt, the Daughter, the first hour she's born, will be bigger than the Mother; however, I will have Mrs. Nan blow high, blow low.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Come, cheer up; for what say you, if Mr. Plot and I get you his consent to Marry your two Mistresses, and give you 3000 l. a piece with them, and 500 l. a year instantly for Mr. Anthony?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hey Boys! This sounds loftiler than the Tutonick.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: If thou dost, take our two late Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: If we do not hang us; but then you must do all we command you, and not lose one moment. Follow us, and depend on it, all shall be done.— Away, away. Exeunt.

div.stage: The SCENE a Chamber, a Bed and Curtains set out within the Scene.
Enter Jenny.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: I doubt he repents, and will not come; yet sure he cannot be such a Rampant Weather, as to give 3000 l. to do nothing. Enter Sir Timothy. Oh, here he is! I see, Sir, Old men are not so punctual at their Amorous Assignments as the Young; 'tis e'en on the stroke of six.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I tell thee, Ienny, 'tis but a little past Five by my Watch.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: A Lovers Watch, especially on such an occasion, should go an hour faster than the Sun. 'Slid, my Lady's at hand; I see her— hide your self behind the Bed.

div.stage: He hides himself behind the Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Had she not come so soon, I would have trifled a little with thee.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: You should not, for I hate Trifling.

div.stage: Enter Betty, who casts her self on her Bed.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am very sick, Ienny; pray draw the Curtains, then run and fetch me a Cordial.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: I will, Madam. Ex. Ienny:

div.stage: Sir Tim. comes from behind the Bed, and opening the Curtains, says

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: She is forward, I might have sav'd 1500 l. of my 3000 l. Niece, I know you are a fair Merchant; I have paid you my money, and now I come for my Commodity.

sp.speaker: Betty
sp.p: startling up. Bless me, Unkle! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What, have you forgot the bargain? I come to be your Bed-fellow, that was our agreement.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But then, I meant you were to be my Bed-fellow as my Sister Nan is.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: But I meant to be your Bedfellow, as a man of Mettle ought to be with a Maid, to whom he has paid 3000 l. for a Nights Lodging.— 'Slid, do you think to Wheedle me? Then 'tis time to Storm you.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Then 'tis time to cry for Rescue.— Help, help.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: within. I come, I come, my Child. Betty tears of his Ruff, and with a kick, flings him down. Betty shrieks, cries for help.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Death, that's my Hagg of a Wifes Voice: I am a lost man, ruin'd for ever, I must hide my self. Runs behind the Bed.

div.stage: Enter hastily, Lady, Philad. Isab. Nan and Winifred.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What shrieks were those, my dear Niece?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ah! Madam! They were mine.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: At what, my Child?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Alas, I saw a Ghost open my Curtains, and it would have Ravish'd me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A Ghost, and would have Ravish'd thee? Thou Dreamst, thou Dreamst.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Pray, in what Shape did it appear?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am loath to tell.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Tell it, I say.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: It was so like Timothy, I durst have sworn it had been he, had not the Lascivious Violence it offer'd me, made me conclude it was the Devil in his Reverend Worships Shape.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Fy, fy, Betty; he, Good Man, a Ravisher? I know him too well to suspect him for that.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, 'twas either he, or Belzebub in his likeness, I'll hold you 3000 l. on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh, the Jade! Betray and jeer me too!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Pray judge whose Ruff this is, that I pluck'd off the Furies Neck, in my own defence. Plucking it out of the Bed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Winifred! Is not this thy Masters Mark?

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: By my Maiden-head, Madam, 'tis; oh, the Old Letcher!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where has he hid himself?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I think behind the Bed, for thither he scuttled when my shrieks call'd in the Company.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Villain, Goat, Cock-Sparrow; come out with a Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Lord! How like a Tarquin he looks. They all go behind the Bed and pluck out Sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Bless me! What an old Ravisher is this?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Forgive me, my dear Wife, it is my first fault of this kind; and, by the Love I bear thee, shall be the last.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Forgive thee, thou Town-Bull? No, if the Law can hang thee, swing thou shalt in the Air. Run, Winifred, and call three Chastizers of the Parish, and let them Worry him.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: I'll fetch those Teasers for him, shall cool his Courage. So Rampant at Sixty! Nay then, 'tis time to Eunuch him. Ex. Winif.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, to show how hot he was, he made me over Mr. Cudden's Judgment of 3000 l. as an offer to corrupt me; here's the very Deed. Gives her a Parchment.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: By this light an 'tis. Ah, thou old Traytor, give 3000 l. to Cuckold me, and Debauch my Niece, by the Injur'd Spirits of thy offended Wife, I'll Mouse thee for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I acknowledge my Crime, and submit, dear Wife of my Bosom: Therefore send not for the Chastizers of the Parish, they'll blaze my dishonour, and so squeeze my Purse, that I shall dye blushing and a Beggar.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, let me interceed for my Unkle.

sp.speaker: Phil. & Isab.
sp.p: We join our Prayers with hers.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hang him Ram!— Nay, since he will be for Feritting in others Burrows, e'en let the Warrener Uncase him, and hang up his Skin, to frighten away all such Vermin.

div.stage: Enter Winifred running.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, by the happiest chance in the World, I met in the Street, just at the door, the three Chastizers of the Parish, newly risen from sitting in Judgment on a young Fornicator, who they have handled without Mittings, and therefore will feague an old Adulterer; I have told them all. They are without at the Door, and if you please I'll bring them in.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: O deliver me not over to these three Tormentors, but Execute me with your own hands rather.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Peace, thou old Sinner, my Ears are barr'd to Mercy; call them in Winifred.
Nan, draw three Chairs, that they may sit in Judgment on this Gray-hair'd Ruffian.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Come in Reverend Sirs. Win. goes to the door.

div.stage: Enter Pedagog, Anthony, and Cudden: the first with a great black beard, the other in black like two Elders; all three humming.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sister, What voice of Justice calleth us hither?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Welcome Sirs— take your Seats; here's the Delinquent; there's the injur'd Innocence; and here's the Witnesses; but the latter we need not, for he confesses the foul fact.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If he confesses, let him be hanged. The proverb has condemned him.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Brother! we must proceed Juridically; set the Delinquent forth! What Crime art thou accused of old Man?

sp.speaker: Sir. Tim.
sp.p: Wenching, and please your worships?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Out upon him, Spawn of the old Serpent, as if wenching pleased us.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Brethren! he's full fraught with Iniquity, his answer is a New guilt.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: At whom, was thy Uncleaness levell'd, old Sinner?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Even at that Gypsy, who has pick'd my pocket of 3000 l.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Mark that Brethren: 3000 l for wenching; he may well pay double as much for pious uses; he's a full spung, Brethren, we must and squeeze him well.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: I am somewhat Tender, Beloved, in erecting Churches out of fornication; the Foundation is bad; but for squeezing him I concur.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Brother, your scruple is not groundless; but since bad manners beget good Laws, 'tis as reasonable that Fornication should build Parochials.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My Hesitations are vanished.

div.stage: Enter Art and Plot.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Sir Timothy, alas! What's the matter? The crowd of people at your door has brought us in.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: And to offer you both our services, if you have need.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: whispers to them. Alas, Gentlemen, you find me in Hucsters Clutches.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ah, for the frailty of my Old Age.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Frailty, in what?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: An Amorous Itch, or so.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Who are those that interrupt our Sessions?

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: And that dare appear before this Court in Roystring Periwiggs, whose Locks are like the Whore of Babylons.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sister Winifred, make these Emblems of Vice withdraw, or at least keep silence. Hems twice. Brethren proceed, let not the Garb of Wickedness put Justice out of its sober pace.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Mr. Plot, and Mr. Art, silence, and hear the Court.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Who is that Female, whom thou, with thy defil'd mouth, didst call Gypsy?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Reverend Sir, 'tis my Niece Mrs. Betty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Mark that, Brethren, his Niece 3000 l. to commit Incest.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: His Niece! O thou obdurate Old Wretch!

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: My Brothers, here's a Covy of Vices complicated; Fornication, as she is a single Woman; Adultery, as he is a Marry'd Man, and Incest as he is an Unkle.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Mr. Thump has Orthodoxly unravell'd and dissected Gradatim, the several Fibers, which grow from this one Wicked Root, viz. Uncleanness.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: But nothing of all this was acted; mark that Reverend Sirs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But 'twas none of your fault 'twas not acted, mark that Irreverend Sir.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: The Fault is foul and clear; therefore let us proceed to Judgment.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: My decree is, that since he is so hot, he shall stand publickly in a White-Sheet by way of Pennance Seven days in Sequence, to Mortify the flames of Lust in the Spectators.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: My Sentence is, that since he could give 3000 l. to one Neece to Corrupt her Chastity, he shall give 3000 l. to the t'other to get her a good Husband; for an old man should bestow at least as much upon Charity as he does upon his Concupiscence.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: E're I proceed, I desire to be informed if any young Women are committed to his ordering?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O Yes, my Sister and I are.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: To our griefs be it spoken.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then my first Sentence is, for I mean to have more than one, That from henceforth you shall be wholly at your own disposal, for he that cannot rule himself, is unfit to guide others.

sp.speaker: Phil. and Isab.
sp.p: I humbly thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Has he any Children or Relations committed to his charge.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes Sir, he has a very hopeful young stripling to his Son, call'd Squire Antony, on whom he will scarce bestow 3 pound: when to quench his Libidiny, he can part with 3000.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: He has also a very promising plant to his Nephew, call'd ' squire Cudden, on whose Estate he has a judgment of 3000 l.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: My Brother has minded me of the decorum of Justice, therefore my second doom is, that he settle forthwith 500 l. a year on Squire Antony, that toward sappling.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And my second decree is, that the said Squire, if he likes the injur'd damsel, shall for his fathers transgression, take her for his loving spouse.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: hems.— And my second decree is, that the Nephew if he likes the other Sister, shall copulate with her, as lawful Man and Wife.— hems lustily. and that the good Lady who the old stallion has so offended, shall henceforth rule the Family; for he has forfeited the Breeches, by being so Rampant after the Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Having thus with sober steps, and well weighed Justice, mov'd through the Criminal part of the Charge; now let us proceed to the Capital.— Adultery, by our Law, requires the Gibbet. Incest, by our Law, the Faggot: So that, believe me Brethren, I doubt we can do no less than Condemn him to be Hanged and Burned.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: For since he fell from Adultery into Incest, it is fit also, that he should fall out of the Frying-Pan into the Fire.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All this must be certify'd to the Governour of the Precinct, to whose Dead-doing Hand we must leave the Transgressor.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay then, Pious Sirs, I must interceed; I cannot forget he is my Husband, though he forget both himself, and that I was his Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
Take pity on me, I beseech you— and to show you I need no severer Judge on my self, than I will be to my self, I freely consent that my Niece Betty keep the 3000 l. Judgment I gave her; and I will give my Niece Nan the like summ
for her Portion. I will also do my utmost endeavour to engage my Son Anthony, and Nephew Cudden, to Marry them. I will settle on the former 500 l. a year, present maintenance, and the rest after my Death; which, alas, I find these abominable Miseries will hasten. My two Charges, Isabella and Philadelphia, I leave freely to their own dispose. And lastly, I will for ever resign up the Soveraignty of the House to my offended Lady; who, I acknowledge, deserves as much to Rule it, as I have made my self hereby unworthy of it. All this I voluntarily do.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let this, I beseech you on my Knees, satisfy your offended Justice.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I unite in their Requests.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I join in it most heartily.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Betty. Isab. Phil. And I.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: And I forsooth.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Brethren, what say ye?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I begin to thaw.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Whipping himself three lashes, is more than if a Beadle Whipp'd him nine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But now I think on't, Brethren, our Office is to punish, not to pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: whispers. That's a severe Assistant, Mr. Plot.
