sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Reverend Sir, consider the greatest part of your Sentence the Delinquent submits to impose upon himself.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Can you be so cruel to deny us all at once?

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: How are we sure he will perform, unless our Decrees are first return'd unto, and then ratify'd by the fore-mention'd Governour of the Precinct.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: If that be all, give me a blank sheet of Parchment, I'll Sign and Seal it▪ then you your selves fit it up according to the Tenour which I have Sworn; which may I perish if I make not good.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Brethren, let us consider. They seem to consult together, and hem often.

sp.speaker: Plot
sp.p: to Isab. Now, Madam, you're at your own dispose, a happiness which when you had attain'd, you promis'd you would perfect mine.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I do remember my Engagement, and here's my hand, I'll keep it. Plot kneels and kisses her.

sp.speaker: Art
sp.p: to Philad. Now you are free, Madam, remember your poor Captive; I do not beg you to break those Chains your Beauties have confin'd me in, but to reward the Joy with which I bore them.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: You have been so respectful and so constant, that I should be more unjust to my self than you, did I not grant your Suit?— Yes, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: The whole Actions of my life shall be to pay my Gratitude.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Call for a Skin of Parchment, ho! Winif. runs out.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: That voice has comfort in't: Ah, my dear Lady, canst thou forgive thy Tim?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Heavens forgive you, I do.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What a Barbarian was I to offend such Innocence; but if my Vertue does not henceforth Geld me, thy Twises shall do that Justice.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: But what if there should be no Parchment ready? 'Twas ill forgotten.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: By the Mass, all then will be Defeated.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, no, I have a help at Maw.

div.stage: Enter Winifred.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: I have search'd over all the House, and cannot find one Skin of Parchment. Is it your pleasure I send to the next Scriveners for one?

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Brother, draw forth your help at Maw; there's need on't now you see▪

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: pulls out the Triple Indenture. Then thus, Brother Thump, I bring it forth.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: to Ant. 'Slid, that's the Triple Indenture.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The very same I profess, and he shall sign the outside of it; for now, as I take it, the Triumvirate is Null'd, and we'll, at leisure, wash out the inside with Aqua Fortis.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Be sure you hold it cleverly then, else all the Fat may be in the Fire.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I warrant thee!— Come, thou Old Miscreant-Penitent, sign your Voluntary-Doom.— Brother yea! Produce your Penner.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: Here, take it, Old Transgressor.— Lord! How his Hand shakes.— Were it to sign 3000 l. for an Incest, he would do it most steadily, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim▪
sp.p: This is my Hand, and this is my Seal, and all that shall be Written above it, according to the Sentence, and my most humble Acquiescence in it, I here, by a fresh Vow, Confirm and Ratify.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: We all are Witnesses to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Now, most Reverend Judges, be not displeas'd if I make one poor and earnest Suit to you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is't Peccator?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis that my Son Anthony, and my Nephew Cudden, may never know of my Transgression, or of the Commutation I make for it, for if they should, their Tyranny would be Intollerable.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Know then, to Console thee— none shall ever be told it, but we that are present; does that satisfie thee?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Most abundantly; and here again then I renew the Oath of my performance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: discovers himself. And thus, with your Blessing, I make bold to possess my self of my part of your Vow! Mrs. Betty, I am yours for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How! My Son Anthony!—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The very same, as I am an Assistant; and have you not a kind Son of me? Who though you banish'd me your House, for showing my Valour in the Streets, does yet, to expiate your fault, cheerfully undergo what you your own self thought (500 l. a year, and 3000 l. in Money) was little enough to buy me to.

Cudden discovering himself. And have you not as kind a Nephew of me? Who tho I was as Tyrannically us'd by you, yet being one of your Judges, condemn'd you to no more than you Sentenc'd your self unto.— Nay, to attone the wrong you did to one Sister, consent to Marry the other with the pittiful Portion of 3000 l. but she is worth a Million. My dear Nan, here take thy own Cudden for ever.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: discovering himself. And have you not a tender Ghostly Father of me, that since I could not reclaim your Worship from Lust as your Schoolmaster, have done it as your Judge?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ha! Bless me!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I have also made bold to use the Liberty your Repentance gave me, and have bestow'd my self on Mr. Plot.

sp.speaker: Philad.
sp.p: And I on Mr. Art.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And since you cannot rule your self, remember you have made your self my Ward.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: And by my Pudicity 'tis fit; for as the Proverb says, Old Men are twice Children, and therefore my good Lady will be your best Guardian.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, I am Noos'd I confess; however, I am glad my shame is confin'd within my own Family.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: How your own Family? Remember, Sir, 'tis my Ladies Family by Decree of the Court.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What, does he break our Sentence, Brethren? Let us fill our Seats of Justice again, and so proceed.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: No, no, we'll fill the blank with a Resignation of all he has, reserving an Annuity of 50 l. a year for himself, and swear to it, and then he'll find we were more merciful as Judges, than as Kindred.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I yield.— This comes of Wenching at Sixty. Pray, Gentlemen, you that will be Wenchers, do not begin so late, else you may pay dear for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cudd.
sp.p: We are all agreed then.

sp.speaker: Pedag.
sp.p: Yes, and all Coupled too; for Winifred and I resolve to be Bed-fellows— during pleasure.—

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: That is during your good Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Methinks just like a Comedy this ends,
Lovers embrace their Loves, and Friends their Friends. Exeunt Omnes.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: OVR next new Play, if this mode hold in vogue,
Shall be half Prologue, and half Epilogue.
The way to please you is easie if we knew't,
A Iigg, a Song, a Rhime or two will do't,
When you're i'th' vein; and sometimes a good Play,
Strangely miscarries, and is thrown away.
That this is such, our Author dares not think,
For what displeases you's a waste of Ink;
And now the Danger of our Thunder's nigh,
We have no refuge but to Mercy fly.
We yield our selves, and you so gen'rous are,
Submitting Foes, though ne'r so great, you'll spare.
Gallants! If y'are offended at our Play,
And think w'have coursly treated you to day,
Think what a famine there is now of Wit,
And that we bring the best that we can get;
Wit's e'en exhausted, and is almost spent,
And you, with little Wit, must be content.
Damn'd Plays shall be adorn'd with mighty Scenes,
And Fustian shall be spoke in huge Machines;
And we will purling Streams and Fire-works show,
And you may live to see it Rain and Snow;
So Poets save their Wit, they care not how.
This all our Scriblers can perform with ease,
Tickle the Fools, tho' not the witty please.
If you expect true Comedy agen,
That represents not Monsters, but shews Men,
Your Expectations will be cross'd, we fear,
For we have little hope to see such here.
